document.title: Syllabus Cambridge International AS & A Level Chemistry 9701

A7A2635D6D16473FA0079192F8AEBFAE.description: deduce the presence of bromine and chlorine atoms in a compound using the M +2 peak

1B58F4103EF8432194D8CED008D360BC.description:
deduce the number of carbon atoms, n, in a compound using the M +1 peak and the formula
n =
100 × abundance of M +1 ion
1.1 × abundance of M + ion

spectrum

BA8E1572E2584AC1B33A62CB60EFE4C6.description:
analyse mass spectra in terms of m/e values and isotopic abundances (knowledge of the working of the mass
spectrometer is not required)

55B6795FBDC248288EC061A9D37D4B46.description:
analyse an infrared spectrum of a simple molecule to identify functional groups (see the Data section for the
functional groups required)

analyse a given synthetic route in terms of type of reaction and reagents used for each step of it, and
possible by-products

products

deduce the presence of a CH3CO– group in an aldehyde or ketone, CH3CO–R, from its reaction with alkaline
I2(aq) to form a yellow precipitate of tri-iodomethane and an ion, RCO2

186786FB147B444D993C314F39B16020.description:
deduce the nature (aldehyde or ketone) of an unknown carbonyl compound from the results of simple tests
(Fehling’s and Tollens’ reagents; ease of oxidation)

describe the use of 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazine (2,4-DNPH reagent) to detect the presence of carbonyl
compounds

EFC8C9A921E446DF8E87F2BE9C26EFBF.description:
describe the mechanism of the nucleophilic addition reactions of hydrogen cyanide with aldehydes and
ketones in 17.1.2(b)

3244406040A743089BBE9A053B9664DA.description:
the reaction of aldehydes and ketones with HCN, KCN as catalyst, and heat to produce hydroxynitriles
exemplified by ethanal and propanone

the oxidation of primary alcohols using acidified K2Cr2O7
 or acidified KMnO4 and distillation to produce
aldehydes

77C8768F2B794D91A0A9C0D5631A26FC.description:
deduce the presence of a CH3CH(OH)– group in an alcohol, CH3CH(OH)–R, from its reaction with alkaline
I2(aq) to form a yellow precipitate of tri-iodomethane and an ion, RCO2

state characteristic distinguishing reactions, e.g. mild oxidation with acidified K2Cr2O7
, colour change
from orange to green

classify alcohols as primary, secondary and tertiary alcohols, to include examples with more than one
alcohol group

1BE9DB60E8A540FA91B7177E13DEBB04.description:
formation of esters by reaction with carboxylic acids and concentrated H2SO4 or H3PO4 as catalyst as
exemplified by ethanol

F5AC938B5AA240BFAC8232992C4415B1.description: dehydration to an alkene, by using a heated catalyst, e.g. Al 2O3 or a concentrated acid

oxidation with acidified K2Cr2O7
 or acidified KMnO4 to:
(i) carbonyl compounds by distillation
(ii) carboxylic acids by refluxing
(primary alcohols give aldehydes which can be further oxidised to carboxylic acids, secondary alcohols
give ketones, tertiary alcohols cannot be oxidised)

9C19603F9CC84C6E943B3309A92BEC5B.description:

heat; or with PCl 5; or with SOCl 2

70D26C8A6DBD455EA84BDB24161A0D44.description: recall the reactions (reagents and conditions) by which alcohols can be produced:

0FCC01FA0379455CA8F10F7EB82FACB0.description:
describe and explain the different reactivities of halogenoalkanes (with particular reference to the relative
strengths of the C–X bonds as exemplified by the reactions of halogenoalkanes with aqueous silver nitrates)

FCEE7CD04BBB4E6FA888841164A43BA1.description:
recall that primary halogenoalkanes tend to react via the SN2 mechanism; tertiary halogenoalkanes via the
SN1 mechanism; and secondary halogenoalkanes by a mixture of the two, depending on structure

F838DE58AFDB4CA19D3F5B129A3DB212.description:
describe the SN1 and SN2 mechanisms of nucleophilic substitution in halogenoalkanes including the inductive
effects of alkyl groups

B076076BB3A44C3E90A929E4AA98ECA3.description:
describe the elimination reaction with NaOH in ethanol and heat to produce an alkene as exemplified by
bromoethane

840D959634644D94B24289D32F8599FF.description:
the reaction with aqueous silver nitrate in ethanol as a method of identifying the halogen present as
exemplified by bromoethane

0D0B9A98F6C34AEFBF1CD9EFDE9F5DB8.description: the reaction with NH3 in ethanol heated under pressure to produce an amine

BAB270BEEBD24C9DBD4BBAF3DE3062FA.description: the reaction with KCN in ethanol and heat to produce a nitrile

9F1F1403AA9F41B38F21105E70741503.description: the reaction with NaOH(aq) and heat to produce an alcohol

6D3CFDBE86A24E19A2BDDE18396D3BE4.description: describe the following nucleophilic substitution reactions:

E9D64471EB80491AB14D8947F113B20E.description: classify halogenoalkanes into primary, secondary and tertiary

74F319B54A084CD48CD1A39719BB9A48.description:
substitution of an alcohol, e.g. by reaction with HX or KBr with H2SO4 or H3PO4; or with PCl 3 and heat;
or with PCl 5; or with SOCl 2

77AA8B0B88C24226B37F12D9B12A5BEE.description: electrophilic addition of an alkene with a halogen, X2, or hydrogen halide, HX(g), at room temperature

3FAF22FE82F94DED90E6053D6A6C73D5.description:
the free-radical substitution of alkanes by Cl 2 or Br2 in the presence of ultraviolet light, as exemplified by
the reactions of ethane

A28DC3A4A788418599C6E2B7A3983A54.description: recall the reactions (reagents and conditions) by which halogenoalkanes can be produced:

5EEDDF49E8624E4C9A812F20AC0E9BB4.description:
describe and explain the inductive effects of alkyl groups on the stability of primary, secondary and tertiary
cations formed during electrophilic addition (this should be used to explain Markovnikov addition)

430EDA51D9AD4C02B3A16BF3C8C77E66.description:
describe the mechanism of electrophilic addition in alkenes, using bromine / ethene and hydrogen
bromide /propene as examples

9F306CB0DFD949069C0194F38E20CBF1.description: describe the use of aqueous bromine to show the presence of a C=C bond

AFE1701309E44D209E89004F2B99F216.description: addition polymerisation exemplified by the reactions of ethene and propene

8F34B37F18F64317902AF98634704F38.description:
the oxidation by hot concentrated acidified KMnO4 leading to the rupture of the carbon–carbon double
bond and the identities of the subsequent products to determine the position of alkene linkages in larger
molecules

96DC266AEB094BD7AAE43EFB80266BBA.description: the oxidation by cold dilute acidified KMnO4 to form the diol

53F33CF42BBF42568907832E2B007115.description:
the electrophilic addition of
(i) hydrogen in a hydrogenation reaction, H2(g) and Pt/Ni catalyst and heat
(ii) steam, H2O(g) and H3PO4 catalyst
(iii) a hydrogen halide, HX(g) at room temperature
(iv) a halogen, X2

6F4D57D5A6374C03A9B092E6074E8E17.description: describe the following reactions of alkenes:

13A52D83B9D04D6AB418DB0EA0137237.description: elimination of HX from a halogenoalkane by ethanolic NaOH and heat

F2F85B51DE284A11A1929BAB13AB7E01.description: recall the reactions (including reagents and conditions) by which alkenes can be produced:

1946401BF1A744548EF4254CD235511A.description:
recognise the environmental consequences of carbon monoxide, oxides of nitrogen and unburnt
hydrocarbons arising from the combustion of alkanes in the internal combustion engine and of their catalytic
removal

25F7FD43DC1A44DFB6D8291E1ECEC851.description:
understand the general unreactivity of alkanes, including towards polar reagents in terms of the strength of
the C–H bonds and their relative lack of polarity

51C0180D766E4A31BE3BF9D95DF5F7E8.description:
suggest how cracking can be used to obtain more useful alkanes and alkenes of lower Mr
 from heavier crude
oil fractions

53B3F4B2B659401AB8EA78ADAA4A552A.description:
describe the mechanism of free-radical substitution with reference to the initiation, propagation and
termination steps

C0B13023131543E19CB705EFB56BD5D5.description:
the free-radical substitution of alkanes by Cl 2 or Br2 in the presence of ultraviolet light, as exemplified by
the reactions of ethane

DE94EA96E70E4DF2B74A9187404FDE0B.description: the complete and incomplete combustion of alkanes

999D98E534B548C29751BDDC66B8195A.description: cracking of a longer chain alkane, heat with Al 2O3

6CF4C15EE72A485BBA8AA8E4D9E927DD.description: addition of hydrogen to an alkene in a hydrogenation reaction, H2(g) and Pt/Ni catalyst and heat

A094A088B26243F8A1D39575EB3E6787.description: recall the reactions (reagents and conditions) by which alkanes can be produced:

4D943D6B6FBE4CAAA249D8E5928BDB99.description: deduce the possible isomers for an organic molecule of known molecular formula

637F80FB8E6343AC81334BE6CF9A1A8A.description:
identify chiral centres and geometrical (cis/trans) isomerism in a molecule of given structural formula
including cyclic compounds

B71C703F2B594DE3A74A4355FB240717.description:
explain what is meant by a chiral centre and that such a centre gives rise to two optical isomers
(enantiomers)
(Candidates should appreciate that compounds can contain more than one chiral centre, but knowledge of
meso compounds, or nomenclature such as diastereoisomers is not required)

B445F1C22DF94B73B38CB690FDA14817.description:
describe geometrical (cis/trans) isomerism in alkenes, and explain its origin in terms of restricted rotation
due to the presence of π bonds

1F15146317024D26BC662D13DAE5AC5A.description:
describe stereoisomerism and its division into geometrical (cis/trans) and optical isomerism (use of E, Z
nomenclature is acceptable but is not required)

170F923717D14D488131102983DF1491.description: describe structural isomerism and its division into chain, positional and functional group isomerism

DF194A100957433D851C9BF3D7D571B9.description:
understand and use the term planar when describing the arrangement of atoms in organic molecules, for
example ethene

5F8CA70AE71446709FAFDC2F5930AD8E.description:
describe the arrangement of σ and π bonds in molecules containing sp, sp2
 and sp3
 hybridised atoms

2E4BBA3EF016441F81C0A4820D7446E1.description:
describe and explain the shape of, and bond angles in, molecules containing sp, sp2
 and sp3
 hybridised atoms

4B97323E1EA84FB48EA15429B0BF057B.description: describe organic molecules as either straight-chained, branched or cyclic

202034C081C748629E006E198EB0348B.description: Shapes of organic molecules; σ and π bonds

D9609FA68C904AFAAB2059C5E83DBC60.description:
oxidation and reduction: (in equations for organic redox reactions, the symbol [O] can be used to represent one atom of oxygen from
an oxidising agent and the symbol [H] one atom of hydrogen from a reducing agent)

02F78E8C2C124A9A81C8EBD3C753436C.description:
free radical, initiation, propagation, termination (the use of arrows to show movement of single
electrons is not required)

57413B089CB5439AAAB7CEA657C60887.description:
deduce the molecular and/or empirical formula of a compound, given its structural, displayed or skeletal
formula

08349E69533A4DB087CD7202F6621D8C.description:
interpret and use the general, structural, displayed and skeletal formulae of the classes of compound stated
in the table on page 26 and 27

CD339390F04C4C5292A75BEB31EFDBAF.description:
understand that the compounds in the table on page 26 and 27 contain a functional group which dictates
their physical and chemical properties

E9136937A0654645A75499BB8B1A354B.description: understand that alkanes are simple hydrocarbons with no functional group

B85432483D76418EB939AE64423296A6.description: define the term hydrocarbon as a compound made up of C and H atoms only

DE1D28C46A3B4A86B52A2AA156441841.description: Formulae, functional groups and the naming of organic compounds

15F2B60A278343C7AD7A532D92A3B5FF.description: An introduction to AS Level organic chemistry

2C5E4346152E42728D8B7946DB5DBAC6.description:
describe the role of NO and NO2 in the formation of acid rain both directly and in their catalytic role in the
oxidation of atmospheric sulfur dioxide

188AD2F398D849D1975684B9414EDA36.description:
understand that atmospheric oxides of nitrogen (NO and NO2) can react with unburned hydrocarbons to
form peroxyacetyl nitrate, PAN, which is a component of photochemical smog

C57617024DE54E1CB1DE142B8EF54611.description:
state and explain the natural and man-made occurrences of oxides of nitrogen and their catalytic removal
from the exhaust gases of internal combustion engines

54D91C267216475AB89858B661EDFA7E.description: the displacement of ammonia from ammonium salts by an acid–base reaction

DDFE0BF4F4DB49908262170A7AFD8986.description: the structure of the ammonium ion and its formation by an acid–base reaction

AB753BFAF82841C5824E7296674ED856.description: the basicity of ammonia, using the Brønsted–Lowry theory

7CF75A44FB6743808CBFAB4F563F40C2.description: explain the lack of reactivity of nitrogen, with reference to triple bond strength and lack of polarity

972E56F7E4FF4168841545D71F5B6417.description:
explain, including by use of an equation, the use of chlorine in water purification to include the production of
the active species HOCl and ClO–
 which kill bacteria.

C531CBF2BFD14282A4938D84FDD15452.description:
describe and interpret, in terms of changes in oxidation number, the reaction of chlorine with cold and with
hot aqueous sodium hydroxide and recognise these as disproportionation reactions

3100B4ECDD9A4DCFAEEABCC78D8A58E0.description: concentrated sulfuric acid, to include balanced chemical equations

65B646B5E5BE4C68A37F7C1BDAF13297.description:
aqueous silver ions followed by aqueous ammonia (the formation and formula of the [Ag(NH3)
2]
+
complex is not required)

30D5D14B345348CEA4BECDA6ED3100CF.description: describe and explain the reactions of halide ions with:

E3B187745CC841A1960F1DD43E64DEF3.description: describe the relative reactivity of halide ions as reducing agents

C7F8CCDB3CF3419E8872FCDDF42963D3.description: Some reactions of the halide ions

B34600DF3EEF479D8E385C0AC8762B71.description: describe the relative thermal stabilities of the hydrogen halides and explain these in terms of bond strengths

AB4243E2E2514B4E912BA2B6069EE6B4.description: describe the reactions of the elements with hydrogen and explain their relative reactivity in these reactions

DA366DBAB6FD4B26869FC745CA18227C.description: describe the relative reactivity of the elements as oxidising agents

B830646A37EE42A39B0468AEDFFD57CC.description: The chemical properties of the halogen elements and the hydrogen halides

BD2EA999C8394C3F8B741B99B231E30B.description: interpret the volatility of the elements in terms of instantaneous dipole–induced dipole forces

8189C2F0249C41239CAB4732212D6F88.description: describe and explain the trend in the bond strength of the halogen molecules

33D3EA30B93B42FFA4B935B58ADAB76D.description: describe the colours and the trend in volatility of chlorine, bromine and iodine

78EC73DB82514CB7994BEFA6BB13F170.description: Physical properties of the Group 17 elements

7AD1F04952C248B3884876F698F5969B.description: state the variation in the solubilities of the hydroxides and sulfates

A83A36266EA14A97BBD139244739D5AF.description:
describe, and make predictions from, the trends in physical and chemical properties of the elements involved
in the reactions in 10.1.1 and the compounds involved in 10.1.2, 10.1.3 and 10.1.5

9D3D55DFDCD149738AAA1FBDC7453FF4.description:
describe, and write equations for, the thermal decomposition of the nitrates and carbonates, to include the
trend in thermal stabilities

4C01F9CA58AD4597B53E9CB3ED0F5951.description:
describe, and write equations for, the reactions of the oxides, hydroxides and carbonates with water and
dilute hydrochloric and sulfuric acids

86CAD29FDF024F55B432409E73E8D409.description:
describe, and write equations for, the reactions of the elements with oxygen, water and dilute hydrochloric
and sulfuric acids

5E6A548889EF45A791731AF38F733D72.description:
Similarities and trends in the properties of the Group 2 metals, magnesium to barium, and their
compounds

6EC199490B7E408693FC48C2952F03D1.description:
deduce the nature, possible position in the Periodic Table and identity of unknown elements from given
information about physical and chemical properties

B1D62EF3C31746D985CAF8CD0E6408AF.description:
predict the characteristic properties of an element in a given group by using knowledge of chemical
periodicity

B8F3361E66D74328A823DC07FD0A28A2.description:
suggest the types of chemical bonding present in the chlorides and oxides from observations of their
chemical and physical properties

6D9302C9CCCF496C8B0C3D396ADB3501.description: explain the variations and trends in 9.2.2, 9.2.3, 9.2.4 and 9.2.5 in terms of bonding and electronegativity

08503C2D0F404236979EE7F0AE17C0C9.description:
describe, explain, and write equations for, the reactions of the chlorides NaCl, MgCl 2, Al Cl 3, SiCl 4, PCl 5
with water including the likely pHs of the solutions obtained

F00B74698578446482A4FF88F1C07D64.description:
describe, explain, and write equations for, the acid/base behaviour of the oxides Na2O, MgO, Al 2O3, P4O10,
SO2 and SO3and the hydroxides NaOH, Mg(OH)2, Al(OH)3 including, where relevant, amphoteric behaviour
in reactions with acids and bases (sodium hydroxide only)

9E5EC373B03E4188A247A2146B49A913.description:
describe, and write equations for, the reactions, if any, of the oxides Na2O, MgO, Al 2O3, SiO2, P4O10, SO2
and SO3 with water including the likely pHs of the solutions obtained

77F716B2CA5B44BEB859FCA1F1B09582.description:
state and explain the variation in the oxidation number of the oxides (Na2O, MgO, Al 2O3, P4O10, SO2 and
SO3 only) and chlorides (NaCl, MgCl 2, Al Cl 3, SiCl 4, PCl 5 only) in terms of their outer shell (valence shell)
electrons

FF0110A4ABAE44D0A0C93C4D3E517E04.description:
describe, and write equations for, the reactions of the elements with oxygen (to give Na2O, MgO, Al 2O3,
P4O10, SO2), chlorine (to give NaCl, MgCl 2, Al Cl 3, SiCl 4, PCl 5) and water (Na and Mg only)

973A24F0A24F4F718BA1A8B9EA630149.description: Periodicity of chemical properties of the elements in Period 3

1F330BB2872D4BC8AD966F925ABD517B.description:
explain the variation in melting point and electrical conductivity in terms of the structure and bonding of the
elements

3D347BF67B384A01969F5F681CC91C9C.description:
describe qualitatively (and indicate the periodicity in) the variations in atomic radius, ionic radius, melting
point and electrical conductivity of the elements

F6A69EBC11664F1BB78FECEC4B76FE38.description: Periodicity of physical properties of the elements in Period 3

ABB398F56CA14524818DC65B3698BD07.description:
construct and interpret a reaction pathway diagram, for a reaction in the presence and absence of an
effective catalyst

9A8A8B7D58C94B31BA079AA5D61FB8F3.description: explain this catalytic effect in terms of the Boltzmann distribution

AE6C3A2FAD314195AADE7551B21A5D42.description:
explain that, in the presence of a catalyst, a reaction has a different mechanism, i.e. one of lower
activation energy

D6F2F21C1B17408C9599794F6FA8BBDC.description: explain and use the terms catalyst and catalysis

6591E91C7E2B4B7C85665AF022E93697.description:
explain qualitatively, in terms both of the Boltzmann distribution and of frequency of effective collisions, the
effect of temperature change on the rate of a reaction
